This one was frustrating and I wasn’t a fan. I like challenging clues and enjoy the lateral thinking crosswords require. But some of these clues were way out there and impossible (for me) to solve. I found this pretty tough, with a solid theme.
That said, I always feel a little ambivalent about themes that feel like they were obviously generated by a python script. I bow to the creator's coding skills, but it just feels a little fake.
It makes me think that soon, we'll be able to tell our AI tools: "Make me a crossword with a theme where several letters can be pushed to the back of the word to make a new word." And AI will do it.
Before we know it, our AI masters will be requiring us to solve their puzzles every day to demonstrate humanity's value to them.

The last square to fall was HAGRI_/_ORY, for which I had to pick from likely possibilities. I almost went with a T, then correctly guessed the D. 

I call a true Natick on the crossing. A sizeable percentage of the population is without kids and thus has little need to imbibe children-related culture. 

Speaking for myself, I have two nephews who have never read Harry Potter because their hyper-religious parents didn’t let them. My eyebrows had met my hairline at this, but that’s another story; the upshot was, though, that I didn’t read Harry Potter either. I now also have two newly acquired—and, oh man, instantly seriously adored—nieces who are both knee-deep in Harry Potter books, and so I will be, too, in very short order, but not everyone has nephews, religion-squashed ones or otherwise, or seriously adored, brand-new nieces. And on behalf of these cruciverbalists I cry, “J’accuse, puzzle editors! Natick on aisle three!”

The pop culture-to-books ratio was definitely higher than 1:1 as per usual, so I insert a mandatory sigh, but I liked the puzzle nonetheless.

Happy Thursday, all.

I eventually figured it all out for myself, but it was ultimately unsatisfying because of my pet peeve: orphaned answers used for a theme gimmick.  BASELINE, RICOTTA, etc. shouldn’t just be left hanging out there with no relation to each other or anything else other than as structural fodder for the theme.  Adding that extra level of meaning would have made this a stellar puzzle.   Don’t ask me how it could be done, I’m not a constructor!

App enhancement request: can the special symbols, like circles, be a different color in “dark mode”? Black is very tough to distinguish from dark grey… I was about to say here (i.e. complain) that the anagrams today were random and not really “circling”, but then saw that Gameplay mentioned the circled letters. Aha.

the gimmick didn't gimmick for me. I like when it closes the loop, so to speak and the word you fill in has some sort of meaning. otherwise it's near-impossible to un-stump yourself if you don't know one of the crossing clues.

eventually I figured out the trick, though it didn't feel like an aha moment, just relief that it would soon be over.

my time was on par, but not super fun.

Yet again, the solution depends on the circles which are INVISIBLE IN DARK MODE. Not sorry for the caps. This is basic accessibility, folks. Use contrasting colors. It was solvable, but unsatisfying. The gimmick was completely unguessable without being able to see the circles.

The crossing clues were gentle enough that I didn't worry too much about with the (quite clever) theme until the end. Rather, I used a modified "Wheel of Fortune" solving style where I don't look at the clue but rather, let my brain complete the missing letters. It's rather fun and so cool that our brains do this for us. MY favorite answer was the sweet and lovely movie, BABE, with the wonderful James Cromwell as Farmer Hoggett. To me, the scene where he sings to Babe is one of the most beautiful scenes in Hollywood and makes me cry every time I watch it: https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=1XEjStkp2LY That'll do pig, that'll do. Happy May Day!

I am a gay man, who happily describes myself as part of the "Queer" community (my Partner, for instance, doesn't). When I was an undergraduate, I was an active participant in the college's Gay Union. At some point , a referendum was held to amend the Union's charter, and name, to reflect the inclusion of lesbians--but whom to give priority? My gal-pal Wendy suggested the "Gay-Lesbian Union" (GLU--Gays and Lesbians sticking together), but in the end we settled on LGU. Later, bi- and transsexuals were appended to the name. Now, the standard has become a veritable mugful of alphanumeric soup, with a flag of such design that would keep Betsy Ross a-stitchin' for ages, and running back to the dry-goods for fresh colors.

As a gay male, and thus arguably floating on the surface of said soup, perhaps should I describe myself as "cis-queer"?

Aidan’s notes did answer a big question – how the heck did they come up with these theme answers, which to me, a word-quirk lover, were amazing. Aside from those theme answers, the stars of this puzzle to me were: • The four long downs (TRÈS CHIC, LIP RINGS, BLANKIES, KEEPSAKE). • A pair of shorter beauts: (MUFFLE, ÉCLAT). • A squeaky-clean grid despite a high 55 squares devoted to the theme. • [Places to carry out some takeout orders, for short?] and [Like does]. That is, a layer of lovely infusing a fun fill-in. A splendid time in the box. Thank you so much for this, Aidan and Adam!

44-Across reminded me of an old linguistics puzzle.

Punctuate the following sentence:

James while Joan had had had had had had had had had had had a better effect on the teacher



....I'll give you a minute...



The answer:
James, while Joan had had "had", had had "had had"; "had had" had had a better effect on the teacher.

If you find this amusing, you're my kind of people.

In case you missed it, see: https://www.nytimes.com/2025/04/28/crosswords/kids-crossword.html?unlocked_article_code=1.D08.A4ZK.24rFEKTBcp49&smid=url-share Two siblings, ages eight and ten submitted a puzzle to the NYT. The link is a brief interview with a link to their puzzle. It would be a great puzzle to send to any young people in your life you'd like to hook on crosswording.

After a few weeks absence, a true Thursday puzzle today. Very clever theme, which, once discerned, certainly helped me complete the puzzle. 

Given the number and placement of the thematic elements, filling the rest of the grid couldn't have been easy. So the (over-?) abundance of proper nouns might be forgiven. That said, the SW corner must have been rough for some folks, with GENOA, INES and DORY crossing HAGRID, AVEENO and DENVER. I knew three of these as clued, and that was enough to salvage that corner of the grid.

Still don't understand the use of horribly clunky clues like "Past-tense verb that's potentially confusing (but grammatically correct!) when written twice in a row". If you can't avoid HAD in your grid, maybe just do "I've ___ it!", rather than calling everyone's attention to your "glue".

KEEPSAKE is an interesting *word* in this sea of names. All in all, a clever and enjoyable puzzle.

It seems like the Eddie-question has reached a slow boil.  Here's my thoughtful contribution:

Some people like to hear what Eddie done did, and some do not.
Those who do should tell him so.
Those who do not should just keep scrolling.
It's important to remember that we can't control the behavior of others, and it only harms oneself to get upset about such small things.

On the other hand, if you "really" don't like Eddie's post, you could reply, "And we're all really very impressed." to his post.
I wouldn't recommend that, however.

I learned to look forward to Tricky Thursdays during the COVID lockdown, when my daughter taught me not to Fear the Rebus but instead to delight in the deductive exercise that was integral to the solve.  The puzzles were often strenuous, but the "Aha!" moment was always very satisfying.  Lately, though, the editors seem to be privileging puzzles where the "trick" is more performative than participatory.  Today is a great example.  Does this puzzle contain clever wordplay?  Absolutely.  But the cleverness is merely incidental to the experience of solving the puzzle; we know something's up but it's not really a "trick" because we don't have to figure it out in order to fill in all the squares lickety-split, even before our coffee has cooled enough to take the first sip.  Kind of a let down.

SW corner has 3 proper nouns and a cryptic clue. What lazy construction

Oats, common grain oats, have the Latin name Avena sativa. Aveeno, the trademark anti-itch lotion, gets its name from the generic name for oats, and for the ability of oats to sooth itching and irritability.

See also Ribena, the trademark name for the drink made from Ribes nigrum, the blackcurrant.

Ribes serves as a host to a fungus destructive of the Eastern White Pine, an important tree in the USA; because of this, blackcurrants are not allowed to be grown here. Though they, and the drink made of them, are very popular in the UK, they are hardly encountered this side of the pond. Forgive our Aveeno and we won’t resent your Ribena.

In Pynchon's "Gravity's Rainbow" he goes through a hilarious section which examines how many meanings you can give "You never did the Kenosha Kid", by the use of punctuation.

For example, the easiest is that the Kenosha Kid is a dance that "you" never did:  You never did "The Kenosha Kid".

Another is whether "you" did something.  "You? Never.  Did the Kenosha Kid?".

Sometimes, I come upon a puzzle where some of the answers just don't make sense, but I get them via the crosses, or they have enough letters from the crosses that I can make a reasonable guess what the "answer" is, even if it doesn't match the clue.

I just make a note that there's some trick to be discovered later, and just move on.

Sometimes, the revealer shows up mid-solve, or late-solve, and everything becomes clear.  In this type of puzzle, there has to be a revealer to make sense of it.

Here, CIRCLES BACK tells me that I have to somehow go BACK to the CIRCLES.  Once I do this, it all makes sense.

People who don't know how to handle this kind of trick may just lack the experience to know what to do.  Hopefully, they'll know for next time.

@Lpr I think the intention is "back" meaning "towards the end" rather than "to the left" ... but also the way I interpreted  it, it's the *reader* circling back, not the circles moving back. So the first pass through the word ignores the  circled letters, and then you circle back -- return to the  topic/word -- and do a second pass that ignores the non-circled  ones.

So, like, for RICOTTA, you read the non circled letters -- RIOTA -- and then go back to the beginning to do the circled ones -- CT

@Vislander "I believe all naticks are personal, revealing what you know or don’t know in certain areas."

The 'natickness" of a particular crossing depends on the number of possible letters which won;t defy the phonotactics of English (or whatever language the entry is from).  In the original--artist _. C. WYETH crossing _ATICK, Mass.--the letter could be any except Q or A, although I concede that "Iatick" or "Uatick" would be odd names for a Massachusetts town; now that I think about it,  "Aatick" could be Dutch-derived. But the usual situation is where only a couple of letters are likely candidates--vowels, say. By my calculation, HAGRI_ crossing _ORY would mostly likely be C, D, R, or T, with other letters more unlikely, although possible.

@Sam Lyons

I also, and for my own heartbreaking reasons, do not have kids. 

Regarding Harry Potter, I was too old to have been interested when the books first came out... and my upbringing also would have forbidden it. I never gave it a second thought. Like you, I was never into fantasy and such. 

Then, in my mid-40s, a friend heartily encouraged, and ultimately convinced, me to to read the books. 

By that point, I knew that our dream of having kids together would never come true and I was still struggling to learn how to carry that tremendous grief. 

Reading Harry Potter was incredibly healing for me. I didn't expect it, but it did happen. There is a scene in the first book in which Harry is very lovingly told, "It does not do to dwell on dreams and forget to live." 

That hit me—hard! 

There are incredibly beautiful themes throughout HP that I'm sure are missed by most children. I've read through them a few times since, though I do not enjoy the movies, and continue to find enlightenment and comfort in them. I hope you will find the same when you read them with your nieces. 

Also, if you do take on more animated films, be warned that the first 10/15 minutes of Up is heartbreaking for anyone who wanted kids, but couldn't for whatever reason. I was literally sobbing and wailing in the theater. It was awful—awful! I had no idea and it hit me out of nowhere. It was beautifully done, mind, but devastating. Grateful it was just my husband and me in the theater.

@HeathieJ

@MExpat - 
A (lecture) class is where the students sit  bored, listening to the teacher yammer on.
A seminar is where the students sit bored, listening to each other yammer on.
A lab is where the students are mutually engaged in individual or group activities toward results:

Laboratory Choir (that was the name of the class) was a staple of my grad school education, where students got credit and/or pay for singing as guinea pigs for other students who got credit for conducting them in order to actively learn the conductor’s art.

Drama lab, art lab, obviously chem lab, electronics lab, architecture lab, … 

I enjoyed seminar teaching most, once I learned what was needed to make sure all of the students were on board. But lab work in the arts is essential: unless you do the actual work in an actual environment where critique (from peers as well as teachers) is an element, you might as well practice at home, if you catch my drift.

Yes, crits can be harsh, even debilitating. But lab work is meant to take dilettantes up to being/becoming artists.

@Rox Since I solved the bottom of the puzzle first, I figured out the "circle back" aspect. You read the non-circled letters first, then go back and add the circled ones to get the answer. AVENGER was my first "a ha," which was really ENGRAVE. So by the time I was filling out the top part (just now), when I got to something that is "read as a stern warning," I looked at the crosses, and I had RI to start. So I thought of RIOT ACT and filled in the non-circled letters and then went back to fill in the circled letters to complete the word, and voila; that's how I came up with RICOTTA. Genius, I say!
